urn:contentItem:60GH-PSV1-F05M-K02R-00000-00Tripadvisor CEO calls for 'enforcement of competition' after Big Tech hearing2020-07-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:19ZLexisNexisTripadvisor CEO calls for 'enforcement of competition' after Big Tech hearingLucia Maffei

The chief executive of one of the largest public technology companies in Massachusetts is taking the side of Congress on some of the anti-competitive practices that were discussed during this week's "Big Tech" congressional hearing, and calling for investigations of Google's search business in particular.

Steve Kaufer, CEO and co-founder of travel metasearch company Tripadvisor Inc. (Nasdaq: TRIP), has long criticized an issue that came under scrutiny during the hearing: the role that Google plays when ranking search results. It's a key issue for Needham-based Tripadvisor, which relies on online traffic to get customers, causing struggles in recent years that have been one factor in the layoffs of hundreds of workers locally.

"The Congressional oversight hearing illustrates the importance of the multiple, global investigations into Google's search business," Kaufer wrote in an email to the Business Journal in response to questions about the hearing. "Tripadvisor welcomes enforcement of competition and consumer protection laws on what Rep. Cicilline described as Google's deceptive efforts to, "[keep] users on Google's sites even if Google doesn't have the most relevant information."

The competition with Google has been causing headaches at Tripadvisor for the past several years. The big problem for Tripadvisor is that Google leverages its map products to occupy larger portions of search result web pages. When people based in the U.S. search for 'San Diego hotels' on Google, the resulting map ends up pushing Tripadvisor's links down on the page, limiting the amount of traffic that would otherwise go to Tripadvisor's website.

Jed Kelly, a senior analyst at Oppenheimer, said earlier this year that this type of competition from Google has been a main driver of Tripadvisor's stock underperformance over the past few years.

During the hearing, Rep. David Cicilline, Democrat of Rhode Island and chairman of the House Judiciary Committee's antitrust subcommittee, accused Google of manipulating its search results to promote its own digital services. "Increasingly, Google just shows whatever is profitable for Google via Google Ads and Google's own sites," he said.

The hearing included some of the most notable names in the whole tech industry. The chiefs of Amazon Inc. (Nasdaq: AMZN), Apple Inc. (Nasdaq: AAPL), Google's parent company Alphabet Inc. (Nasdaq: GOOG) and Facebook Inc. (Nasdaq: FB) were all grilled before Congress about their companies' practices as part of an investigation on market dominance in the industry.

It's unclear, however, what direct impact the hearing will have on how the biggest tech companies in the world are regulated.

Dan Wasiolek, a senior equity analyst at Morningstar who covers Tripadvisor's stock, said that these hearings don't often lead to much change in the U.S.

"In Europe, they're more aggressive on protecting consumer interests," he said.

Last year, the European Commission finedGoogle (EURO)1.49 billion for breaching EU antitrust rules.

urn:contentItem:5XJY-6411-DXH2-6024-00000-00TripAdvisor Inc at Phocuswright Conference - Final2019-11-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:19ZLexisNexis112019a12913597.797TripAdvisor Inc at Phocuswright Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Stephen Kaufer

TripAdvisor, Inc. - Co-founder, President, CEO & Director

Conference Call Participants

* Alice Jong;Phocuswright Inc.;Research Manager

Presentation

ALICE JONG;PHOCUSWRIGHT INC.;RESEARCH MANAGER: Our next speaker has led one of the most recognized travel brands best known for its traveler reviews for nearly 2 decades. He has diversified the company into hotel search, activity booking, restaurant reservations and more. Please welcome the President and CEO of TripAdvisor, Steve Kaufer.

Thanks so much for joining us again this year.

STEPHEN KAUFER, CO-FOUNDER, PRESIDENT, CEO & DIRECTOR, TRIPADVISOR, INC.: My pleasure. Always fun to be here.

Questions and Answers

ALICE JONG;PHOCUSWRIGHT INC.;RESEARCH MANAGER: So a year ago, when we were up here on the stage together, you had just announced the new TripAdvisor, which includes a travel social feed. So how has that been going in the past first year?

STEPHEN KAUFER: We love it. It's a great step forward in terms of how we try to personalize the experience. TripAdvisor has always been around helping other -- helping people help other people plan that trip. It's really what differentiates us. It's the secret sauce. It's the millions in -- practically billion reviews out there. If you take those reviews and you now combine it with those famous names, those influencers, those other sources of trusted opinions, it makes such a nice map.

So you take the travel feed in there, you take other personalization elements that are coming, you take more info from people like me and that's really what we believe will help make the best travel trip.

ALICE JONG;PHOCUSWRIGHT INC.;RESEARCH MANAGER: Now travel inspiration is a state of the funnel that no travel company has truly won or dominated yet. We see a lot of failed start-ups that try and do it. So what have been some of the big learnings as you guys made this foray up into the inspiration stage?

STEPHEN KAUFER: It's really hard. I've seen a number of companies really trying to do an excellent job at inspiring travelers. But to have an economic model that just inspires and then say, hey, go off, finish the trip later hasn't worked really for anyone. TripAdvisor is in a unique position because we can do the inspiration, we can have amazing pictures, video, and again, back to that social feed, reasons why I'd love to take that trip, I'd be inspired. And now we're not sending you somewhere else, we're actually helping you plan the trip.

You click the little heart icon and you save into an itinerary all the different things that you want to do. You're looking at where you're going to stay, you're going to look at the fun things to do and you're going to be inspired by all the different pieces of content. As we help you through that travel planning process, we're there to guide you and we want to do more when you're in destination, taking that trip with you, et cetera.

So as you see, it's the whole picture that really makes inspiration come to life.

ALICE JONG;PHOCUSWRIGHT INC.;RESEARCH MANAGER: Now when you first launched the travel feed, content from brands, right, it was -- you didn't have positions for sponsored content or ads yet. So is that still the case now?

STEPHEN KAUFER: It's not really -- it never was the focus. We weren't trying to build the Facebook or the Twitter of travel. You're trying to help travelers. At the end of the day, looking for that juicy, that inspiring bit of content that could really help make or break this particular trip. So we look at it from the point of view of if that content is what we think is the most relevant to you, the travel planner at that moment in time, that's what we want to put there. If we think a better recommendation for something to do, not from the social feed but from other people like you or from our recommendation engine, that's what we want to put in front of you. Again, all to help that travel planning process.

ALICE JONG;PHOCUSWRIGHT INC.;RESEARCH MANAGER: So are there paid spots then within the travel feed now?

STEPHEN KAUFER: There might be, but I mean it's so not a focus of ours. We have a fabulous media business. It's growing annually and we expect it to double in the next 3 to 5 years. It's media for major advertisers, major brands. And actually, this morning, we just announced a TripAdvisor media manager. This will allow smaller brands, smaller companies to come on -- come on to the site, buy a particular audience looking to go to a particular destination, practically self-service. Again, it's the close to 0.5 billion monthly eyeballs that we have on the site, people with high intent trying to figure out where to go, what to do when they get there and that's really quite valuable to perhaps a whole bunch of people in the audience here.

ALICE JONG;PHOCUSWRIGHT INC.;RESEARCH MANAGER: Yes. And I know you guys had mentioned that media and advertising is going to be an important source of growth for you now that the hotel metasearch growth has kind of slowed. So my question is, is it going to be difficult to maintain a good user experience when you have to focus so much on ads?

STEPHEN KAUFER: Great question. Not a problem for us. When we think about it, and you can look throughout our history, we've really done, we feel, a very good job focusing on the traveler, helping that traveler figure out where they want to go, what they want to do and all the different options. Now here's an opportunity for a travel brand, be it a hotel, a thing to do, a place to go to say, hey, you should consider our destination or our property, especially with our dynamic ads where a hotel, for instance, can put our bubble rating right on the ad, a sign of, hey, it's not just a bit of marketing material, it's an opportunity to engage a traveler and pick my property, my attraction, my destination.

There's so many great places to go, so many wonderful things to see. If the ads are relevant, which on our site, they are; if they are served in the timely and noninvasive manner, you don't have the things popping up, taking over your screen, you have contextual, personalized advertising. And that's we -- I mean, obviously, it's the way we choose to do it. It's the way we think advertising works best.

ALICE JONG;PHOCUSWRIGHT INC.;RESEARCH MANAGER: Great. So you guys recently announced an alliance with Trip.com Group, Ctrip, over in China having a JV. So what's in it for you guys? Tell us why you decided to do this.

STEPHEN KAUFER: We think it's a great partnership. So we've been in China for quite a few years. And as you saw just a few minutes ago, the market in Asia in general, and China in particular, continues to grow by leaps and bounds. So many of these travelers are traveling for the first time and then another set that are taking their first international trip and another set that are becoming international travelers in general, repeat visits.

We looked at our offering and then we looked at what could our offering do with the assistance of another major player, and frankly, who better to pick in the marketplace than someone like Ctrip or Trip.com Group. Tremendous industry knowledge, the ability to look at the demand that's on both their sites and on TripAdvisor, craft a package that's really suitable for the outbound audience and deliver that. We benefit from some of the supply. We benefit from a minority ownership in this joint venture. And it's -- as many would say, partnership isn't right way to tackle a market or to address an opportunity that may not be in our core wheelhouse.

ALICE JONG;PHOCUSWRIGHT INC.;RESEARCH MANAGER: And as you mentioned, you've been in China for a number of years, almost a decade, right? And so you had a rebrand there a couple of years back as well. So why the JV route now?

STEPHEN KAUFER: Well, if you wind back the clock, we started as, hey, let's replicate the TripAdvisor model in China, period, full stop. That didn't get enough traction to our liking so we really focused on where we thought we could be unique, which was the outbound travel, leveraging our point of interest database, all the different things and really did it quite well for a number of years. But you have to have -- you have to have fortitude, you have to have amazing content, you have to play by the rules that exist in China. And for us to achieve the next level -- we could have kept going as we were. But to really achieve the next level, to have that shot at greatness in that marketplace, we felt partnership was the clear right way to do things. And there are several partners that we had considered. We thought Ctrip, obviously, given their strength in the -- or Ctrip.com Group, given their strength in the travel category, would be the perfect partner.

ALICE JONG;PHOCUSWRIGHT INC.;RESEARCH MANAGER: And so they invested just north of $300 million or so, right? So is that a down payment for something bigger?

STEPHEN KAUFER: Let's just say, TripAdvisor, being a category of one in the travel ecosystem, close to 500 million unique users, 800 million reviews that we, by an Oxford Economics study, influence 10% of all global travel. It's just an incredible number. Ctrip, of course, or Trip.com Group and perhaps others would look at TripAdvisor and say, ooh, this could be quite interesting as part of a bigger company. I don't think about that. I think about running TripAdvisor. I think about helping the next billion travelers, wherever they live, in all of our different categories of opportunity.

ALICE JONG;PHOCUSWRIGHT INC.;RESEARCH MANAGER: Okay. So you have been very transparent with how Google has been impacting TripAdvisor's business as they stuff their page more with ads and with their own travel products so...

STEPHEN KAUFER: I like the way you phrased it, stuff their page more with ads. That's perfect. I'm going to use it.

ALICE JONG;PHOCUSWRIGHT INC.;RESEARCH MANAGER: So what can online travel companies do to stay relevant and battle that slip in value as Google makes stronger moves into the space?

STEPHEN KAUFER: A challenge for us, a challenge for many, many travel companies, a challenge for a whole lot of different companies in verticals completely different than travel. When you look at how they have stepped forward and said, look, anyone on Google should essentially stay on Google. It's more and more the traffic. I'm a believer that, that's a challenge for the Internet ecosystem, period. People love Google as a search engine. Please stay a search engine to help people find the best things that's out there.

The competitive landscape when it gets concentrated just becomes a burden on innovation everywhere. What can TripAdvisor do about it? What can other companies? We have to build better products. We have to build and deliver the value proposition to travelers so that the next time you plan that trip, you'll come direct to TripAdvisor, you'll open up our app. You won't start at any search engine, Google included.

ALICE JONG;PHOCUSWRIGHT INC.;RESEARCH MANAGER: Looks like we have an audience question.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Steve, thanks for being here. On the last earnings call, you talked about plans next year to reintroduce a completely new mobile app. Can you just give us a sense of what to expect? And maybe what some of the driving principles are that you're thinking about as you redevelop the mobile app?

STEPHEN KAUFER: Sure. Great question. So when you think of our mobile app today, it looks reasonably similar in functionality and navigation to our desktop application and to our mobile application. Yet when you think about travel in general, there's 2 rather distinct phases at least. First, I'm planning the trip. Not too many people want to arrive and then figure out where they're going to stay. So there's how do I get there, where am I going to stay and maybe some iconic things that I want to make sure I do when I get there. That's travel planning in advance.

And then I arrive, and maybe I haven't selected all the places I'm going to eat. Maybe I kept an afternoon free in order to experiment, to play. I still need in the moment to be able to figure out what's the best thing to do. Where do I want to eat? What type of food does my family wish to eat tonight? And what's the best restaurant near where I'm actually standing?

And so we have a lot of that functionality already on the site or in the app, but is it convenient for an in-destination use case? And our answer is not nearly enough. So the app actually has to do double duty in terms of I download it and I use it as a travel planning tool. I create my itinerary. I put all the things I'm interested in it. And it's not a fully planned itinerary most of the time. I arrived in destination and now how can I get everything that's contextual to where I am, to what I want to do right now, nonavailability 2 weeks out, but availability this afternoon. And bringing those things to the forefront with different navigation, we expect will deliver a much better app experience.

ALICE JONG;PHOCUSWRIGHT INC.;RESEARCH MANAGER: Great. So I have one more question on Google. So back in 2010-ish, right, when Google was talking about buying ITA, there was an alliance that was formed, FAIR SEARCH, it included you, a couple of the other big brands, Expedia, KAYAK, where you guys lobbied together against this. Is this a good time to maybe rally back your old friends?

STEPHEN KAUFER: Well, I think we do have a different landscape in terms of the political landscape now, both in the EU and in the U.S., looking at activities around big tech companies and what they can do with the power that they have. I think that scrutiny is a great thing. I think it doesn't have to lead to explicit regulation, but I think holding everyone to make sure that they're truly always acting in the consumer's interest. And when you've accumulated monopoly power, I think there is a special obligation to make sure that the rest of the ecosystem thrives.

ALICE JONG;PHOCUSWRIGHT INC.;RESEARCH MANAGER: Now Experiences, right, is another important segment for you guys and you have the first-mover advantage. But now as GetYourGuide and Klook, they're having big piles of money behind them, Airbnb is investing in tickets, how are you going to ensure that you stay ahead in this space?

STEPHEN KAUFER: Well, a big pile of money is wonderful to have, but it does not actually deliver a great consumer experience as someone is traveling. And so TripAdvisor and Viator are blessed with millions of travelers a day who are planning a trip somewhere. And it's generally a considered vacation, it tends not to be a 1-night stay. What makes that vacation amazing? Yes, the lodging is an important piece, but what else are we going to do there? So having the footprint of supply that we have, adding the recommendations, the curation, the other ways that is certainly within our capabilities of being able to deliver that inspiring trip, the thing you really want to come home and rave about, that's what builds the loyalty we're looking for. That's what builds the desire for people or the feeling that, of course, I had a great time on this trip. Thank you, TripAdvisor. Not the transaction. I actually bought the ticket, that's nice. That's some of the frictionless stuff you talked about, it's a -- you need to have it. But the discovery and the actual adventure that you took, that's what makes the memories and that's what we're aiming for.

ALICE JONG;PHOCUSWRIGHT INC.;RESEARCH MANAGER: And how are you helping the travelers discover what they should be doing, right? So with activities, one of the hardest things is that you're really plagued by choice, right, in the segment. So aside from, yes, making things digital and bookable online is great. But beyond spitting out a laundry list of potential things in a single city, like what are you doing to help them identify this is what's for me?

STEPHEN KAUFER: Great question. And I'd say we have -- we're in early, early innings in being able to do a good job at that. When I'm a traveler and I'm using TripAdvisor and I see all the things, I do feel like I have a lot of choice, yay, but I wish it was easier. I wish TripAdvisor or any site knew me a bit better and I wish the experiences, the ways I could form my days were sort of better advised, better recommended so that I could enjoy the actual activity even more than I enjoy the planning.

And I'd like to plan. I'd like to figure out what I want to do. But I, of course, don't need to wade through all the other products that I'm not interested in. And frankly, I'm willing to tell a site, TripAdvisor, a bit about what I'm looking for in order to get better results. If I can get those results and I make that happy trip and my family is happy, then I'm good to go.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Alice, we've got a question on Slido for Steve. Mafengwo is often called the TripAdvisor of China. How do you respond to that?

STEPHEN KAUFER: Well, I'd say the joint venture is one way that we have responded to that. Mafengwo is very good company. They have a fair amount of traffic. They have a lot of content. They are certainly respected. On the other hand, TripAdvisor with Trip.com Group brings the ability to not only talk about where to go, not only the trust factor that you get from 800 million opinions on things all around the world, but also the security of being able to finish the transaction, buy it on Tripadvisor.cn or on Ctrip or Trip.com or any of our collective sites. So I think it's early days still in the travel landscape in China. We found a fantastic partner and so I think we'll do quite well there.

ALICE JONG;PHOCUSWRIGHT INC.;RESEARCH MANAGER: So TripAdvisor, you guys are celebrating your 20th birthday next year in 2020. Did you plan that? And so you're one of the last remaining from that early wave of online travel that has remained CEO of the company that he founded. So how do you continue to innovate and inspire and stay motivated through all these changing times?

STEPHEN KAUFER: A great challenge. And I do think TripAdvisor has done a good job innovating, trying new things, building out new pieces. Some work better than others. That's just an aspect of being in the travel space and being willing to take risks. Of course, I wish all the things that we've tried had worked beautifully. But I don't regret, even with the benefit of hindsight, giving the things a go. We have tremendous assets at our disposal in terms of cash flow, in terms of points of interest, in terms of traffic, in terms of supply, in terms of trust of travelers. How do we better use that to deliver on that end story? I'm still here because we haven't solved that problem. We're not anywhere near the point of like optimizing a flow of something and getting an extra point or 2 out. Us and so many other companies in this room are clearly innovating in ways to help generate the type of travel excitement that we've seen in the past 20 years, going forward for 20 more.

ALICE JONG;PHOCUSWRIGHT INC.;RESEARCH MANAGER: Awesome. Thank you so much for joining us on stage again this year. Ladies and gentlemen, Steve Kaufer.

STEPHEN KAUFER: My pleasure. Thank you all.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:41KP-VN00-009B-G53F-00000-00Triple-Digit Surge for the Dow on Eve of Presidential Election; Cisco Reports Profits After the Bell; Who Won the Dash for Campaign Cash?2000-11-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:19ZLexisNexisCNN MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR 18:30David Jones, Robert Brusca, John ChambersBusinessSHOW00110600V19Triple-Digit Surge for the Dow on Eve of Presidential Election; Cisco Reports Profits After the Bell; Who Won the Dash for Campaign Cash?Stuart Varney, Willow Bay, Allan Chernoff, Bruce Francis, Terry Keenan, Kelli Arena, Joie Chen, Casey Wian, Amanda Lang, Terry Keenan, Greg Clarkin

While everyone agrees that its the closest contest in decades, investors today seemed to be betting on a winner in George W. Bush. Stocks that would potentially benefit from a Bush administration shot higher, and blue chips overall seemed to benefit from a flight to safety in the midst of the political uncertainty. Plus, as the most expensive election season in political history winds down, who won the dash to collect the most campaign cash? While Cisco didn't disappoint with after-the-bell numbers, it didn't quite dazzle either. The company earned 18 cents a share, maintaining a long tradition of beating expectations by a penny.

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

STUART VARNEY, CNN ANCHOR: Tonight on MONEYLINE, a triple-digit surge for the Dow, ahead of the biggest presidential cliffhanger in decades. Is Wall Street betting on a Bush win?

WILLOW BAY, CNN ANCHOR: After the bell a much anticipated report from a pivotal Nasdaq name: profits from Cisco. We'll talk with CEO John Chambers.

VARNEY: As the contenders wage a last-minute battle for votes, we'll look at who won the dash for campaign cash in history's most expensive election.

ANNOUNCER: This is MONEYLINE. Reporting tonight from Los Angeles, Willow Bay and from New York, Stuart Varney.

BAY: Good evening, everyone, and welcome to MONEYLINE. I'm Willow Bay.

VARNEY: And I'm Stuart Varney.

Our top story tonight: a pre-election rally for the Dow. Americans won't begin casting their votes in the presidential election for 12 hours or more. And while everyone agrees that its the closest contest in decades, investors today seemed to be betting on a winner in George W. Bush. Stocks that would potentially benefit from a Bush administration shot higher, drug stocks in particular. And blue chip stocks overall seemed to benefit from a flight to safety, in the midst of the political uncertainty.

The Dow broke back above 11000 at its high today. It ended with a gain of 159 points at 10977. The volume came in at about 930 million shares.

But the Nasdaq was under pressure all day long, awaiting after- the-bell profits from Cisco. It fell 35 points to 3416. The volume there was nearly 1.6 billion shares. The S&P 500 gained 5 1/2 points. It ended at 1432.

Allan Chernoff looks at today's Dow rally and Wall Street's focus on 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) ALLAN CHERNOFF, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Wall Street appears to be betting on a Bush victory. Industries to which Governor Bush has been relatively sympathetic rose in today's trading. Most important: pharmaceutical companies, Merck, Shering-Plough, American Home Products, Pfizer and Lilly among the winners, an early relief rally following Vice President Gore's attacks on drug makers.

AL GORE, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: It's just wrong for seniors to have to choose between food and medicine while the big drug companies run up record profits.

CHERNOFF: Managed health care stocks were higher except for Wellpoint, which has lost ground in recent days after a huge rally in October. Bush favors restricting the right to sue HMOs, while Gore wants to expand that right.

RONALD HILL, BROWN BROTHERS HARRIMAN: It does look like some of the stocks, which would do reasonably well under a Bush victory are sort of leading the charge upwards, especially in health care sector.

CHERNOFF: Defense and aerospace stocks were mainly higher. General Dynamics, Lockheed Martin, and Northrup Grumman climbing, while Boeing was unchanged in spite of a downgrade from Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. A reaction, analysts say, to the governor talking tough.

GOV. GEORGE W. BUSH (R-TX), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: And America's armed forces need better equipment, better training and better pay.

CHERNOFF: Microsoft resumed its recent climb, up 1 1/4, partly on speculation that a Republican administration might ease pressure for a Microsoft breakup.

Governor Bush has said he would drop the Justice Department suit against tobacco companies. And today their stocks withstood the negative news the Engle class action case was sent back to the Florida state judge who oversaw the $145 billion jury award against the industry. Phillip Morris lost only 1/8 of a point. R.J. Reynolds, which has also been rallying lately, was off 3/8.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CHERNOFF: And the bond market was anticipating a Bush victory as well today. The long bond down 12/32 in late trading on concerns that the governor's tax cut plan could very quickly eat away the federal surplus. As for the stock market, if Bush does win, there will not necessarily be a big market rally. We all know the old Wall Street adage: buy on the rumor, or in this case, the poll, sell on the news -- Stuart.

VARNEY: Well, said, Allan Chernoff. Thanks very much Allan.

Well, on the eve of the election, let's take a look at where we stand in the markets so far this year. The Dow is down 4 1/2 percent in 2000. The last time it hit a record high was January 14th. The Nasdaq is off 16 percent and down more than 32 percent from its last record, which it hit on March 10th.

BAY: The election, as we've said, wasn't the only event Wall Street was waiting for today. Tech investors were anxious ahead of Cisco's profit report, the company considered a pillar of the Nasdaq. And while Cisco didn't disappoint with after-the-bell numbers, it didn't quite dazzle either. The company earned 18 cents a share, maintaining a long tradition of beating expectations by a penny. Sales jumped more than 65 percent to $6.5 billion. That wasn't enough for investors trading the stock in after hours, the shares fell 1 1/2 after losing ground in the regular session.

Bruce Francis has been listening to the company conference call and he joins us now with the very latest on the results and, of course, the outlook -- Bruce.

BRUCE FRANCIS, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Willow, thanks.

Cisco's results delivered no negative surprises. That alone makes Cisco stand out alongside stumbling competitors like Lucent and Nortel. Here are some of the highlights of the quarter: CEO John Chambers bragged that Cisco's bottom line is benefiting from good geographic and product line balance, something that he vows to communicate better to Wall Street. Sales to enterprise, so-called "corporate customers," were robust, as companies beef up their information technology infrastructures.

But Cisco did acknowledge that smaller, scrappier competitive telephone companies are spending at slower rates than before. Cisco sees 2001 revenues rising 50-60 percent, including a sequential increase in the coming Q2, the current quarter, this will prompt many analysts to raise their earnings numbers, but since that faster growth comes from slightly less profitable products, profit margins will decrease.

CEO Chambers says that he was more concerned now about the U.S. economy and demand from telecom companies than he was before. And Cisco spelled out its loan arrangements with its customers, something Wall Street has been worried about, but maintained that the portfolio is managed conservatively.

Well, looking out further, analysts are expecting Cisco's revenues to grow anywhere from 23-50 percent in 2002. The company is telling the street right now to keep those projections right where they are -- Willow.

BAY: Bruce Francis reporting -- thanks, Bruce.

FRANCIS: My pleasure.

BAY: Later on MONEYLINE, we'll talk with John Chambers, the CEO of Cisco, just minutes after he finishes up the company conference call with analysts.

VARNEY: Cisco was one factor holding the Nasdaq back today, but there was no stopping the Dow, where some of the oldest of the old- economy stocks took off ahead of voting tomorrow. Let's go to Terry Keenan at the New York Stock Exchange with a look at the big board standouts -- Terry.

TERRY KEENAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT: And, Stuart, there are a lot of them. Well, there was a lot of talk here that this pre-election rally was signaling a Bush victory at the polls tomorrow. No one was really getting too excited about the outcome, noting that election years and particularly the eve of a presidential election is usually a good time for stocks.

The Monday before Election Day in both 1996 and the more hotly- contested election in 1992, stocks did rally in advance of Election Day, although today's gains were stronger on a percentage basis. A lot of traders here were also pointing to strong mutual fund inflows in early November and that seems to have increased the appetite for stocks by money managers.

Whatever the reason, the Dow had another strong day. Helping out to the upside, J.P. Morgan, this after its merger partner Chase said that the combination will add even more to earnings going forward than they initially expected. Financials as a group pretty strong today, as were those old-economy stocks, the economically-sensitive issues.

Look at that move in GM, back above $60 a share. 3M and United Technologies also enjoying standout sessions, while AT&T, one of the few losers, down another 50 cents. As for the market breadth, just slightly positive, as you can see there by 35 stocks. Trading action, though, was light, 10 percent below recent levels, not surprising ahead of both the Cisco numbers and tomorrow's election -- Stuart.

VARNEY: Well, during the day tomorrow, can't investors get some indication of how the vote is going from somewhere or other tomorrow? Because that could affect trading.

KEENAN: It definitely could, because trading is open for the full day. And there really isn't much expectation that traders will have a look at the exit polls, but there was some buzz today whether that key exit polling information might be available on the Internet. Now, television networks keep this information very close to the vest, and it's actually accumulated by a company, a consortium of the different television networks.

But some Web sites, most notably Matt Drudge, did publish some exit polls during the primaries, and Mr. Drudge says that if he can get his hand on that information, he will put it on his Web site tomorrow -- Stuart. So stay tuned.

VARNEY: Which means the stock market could become a leading indicator for the polls tomorrow night.

KEENAN: If that information becomes available, we'll have to see.

VARNEY: We shall. Terry Keenan at the big board, thanks -- Willow. BAY: Stuart, coming up next, what just may be a photo finish in the race for the White House. We'll have the very latest poll numbers, as the candidates zero in on the battleground states.

And later, a spectacular tumble for VA Linux: What ever happened to Linux, the software that was going to shatter the Windows monopoly?

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: Now, a special MONEYLINE look at the race for 2000, the most expensive election season in political history. "The Washington Post" today offered up its own tally for spending in the presidential and congressional contests: a total of $3 billion. And it was clear early on that the campaign trail to the White House would be paved in cash, when Governor Bush raised more than a hundred million dollars just to win the primary.

Kelli Arena looks at how much money the candidates raised and where it came from.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

KELLI ARENA, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): The stakes are admittedly high.

SCOTT HARSHBARGER, COMMON CAUSE: You have money and power intersecting in the search for the most powerful office in the free world.

ARENA: But the numbers nonetheless are staggering.

LARRY MAKINSON, CENTER FOR RESPONSIVE POLITICS: If Alan Greenspan were monitoring inflation in political spending, he probably would have had a heart attack by now.

ARENA: Despite all the rhetoric about campaign finance reform, the fund-raising cycle is as vicious as ever. Check the tally: George W. Bush pulling in $187 million in hard money, that's money that goes directly to his campaign, and $129 million in soft money, that's money that goes to the Republican Party; Al Gore, $133 million in hard money, $91 million in soft money.

Much of that soft money coming from the usual coffers, labor unions, law firms, oil and tobacco companies. But there's also a new kid on the block.

HARSHBARGER: The most significant new player really is the high- tech community, and particularly, Microsoft.

ARENA: Microsoft and other high-tech firms have donated $24 million so far this election cycle.

MAKINSON: The biggest movement we've seen this year by far has been the rise of the computer industry. A decade ago, the computer industry was 55th among the 80 or so industries that we track, today they're number 8. ARENA: But unlike labor unions, which give more than 90 percent of their money to Democrats, and oil companies, which give 80 percent to Republicans, high-tech firms are hedging their bets.

PETER EISNER, CENTER FOR PUBLIC INTEGRITY: The interest of corporations is to have access to power no matter who wins and to be able to influence policy.

ARENA: Much of the money raised is being spent on advertising, and with polls showing the candidates running neck and neck, most of the ads are running in swing states.

EISNER: Between 60-70 percent of all money is spent on one form or another of media advertising. We're talking about a system in which $500-$600 million will be spent on television and radio in this cycle, which is at least a quarter more than 1996.

ARENA: There are also issue ads, put out by special interest groups.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP, NRA AD)

NARRATOR: Al Gore wants government testing, licensing and registration for all firearms operators.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ARENA: The money spent on those ads are not included in soft money tabulations, but it's estimated that about $300 million was doled out by special interest groups this year.

MAKINSON: When they put those ads on the air, they do not file a report with the Federal Election Commission as long as they don't use the magic words of saying vote "for" or vote "against." These are so- called "issue ads."

ARENA: Those ads are the most troubling to campaign finance reform advocates who say the entire fund-raising effort has spun way out of control.

HARSHBARGER: Reform is really about not taking money out of politics, it's taking the abuse of money out of politics. It's making it that money doesn't influence who gets to play.

ARENA (on camera): And despite all the money being spent, voter turnout is still expected to be less than 50 percent.

Kelli Arena, CNN Financial News, Washington.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

VARNEY: The top of the ticket wasn't the only race that saw candidates shelling out really big bucks. According to the Center for Responsive Politics, the heftiest price tag was in the New Jersey state Senate campaign, where former Goldman Sachs executive Jon Corzine spent more money than any senatorial candidate in history, shelling out $55 million of his own money. Across the Hudson River, New Yorkers have watched Rick Lazio raise $33 million, outpacing the $22 million taken in by Hillary Rodham Clinton. And another milestone was set in a California congressional race, where incumbent James Rogan and challenger Adam Schiff raised a combined total of $10 million, and that too, is a record.

BAY: On this final day before the U.S. elections, our special edition of the MONEYLINE "News Digest: Election 2000."

Joie Chen is at the CNN Center and she joins us now with the day's political news -- Joie.

JOIE CHEN, CNN ANCHOR: Thank you, Willow.

The presidential candidates stormed across the country today, appealing for votes on this last full day of campaigning before tomorrow's elections. Vice President Gore and Texas Governor George W. Bush followed grueling, almost round-the-clock schedules, looking to win support in the key battleground states. Gore had events today in Iowa, Missouri and Michigan. He is closing the day in Florida, where he and Bush are still in a tight race for that state's 25 electoral votes, and where Gore said he expects to clinch the election. While in Missouri, the vice president charged that Bush has set the wrong priorities for the country.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

AL GORE, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Governor Bush would propose under his plan to spend more money on tax cuts to the top 1 percent than all of his new proposals for education, health care, and national defense combined. Now, those priorities are wrong for America.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CHEN: Bush, too, was on a marathon campaign schedule, starting in Tennessee, another state where the two are locked in a close race. Bush was in traditional Democratic territory all day, stopping in Wisconsin, Iowa and Arkansas. While in Tennessee, Bush predicted he would take the vice president's home state.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GOV. GEORGE W. BUSH (R-TX), PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE: My opponent vows to carry his home state. He may win Washington, D.C., but he's not going to win Tennessee.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CHEN: Governor Bush tonight heads home to Texas to await the results of tomorrow's vote. Gore heads home to Tennessee tomorrow.

The latest polls show that the race for president is closer than ever. Results from the two-day poll by CNN/"USA Today" and Gallup show while Gore is up 2 percentage polls from previous polls, Bush still holds a narrow lead among the likely voters, 47 percent to Gore's 45 percent. A six-day average of the same tracking poll shows Bush winning support from 47 percent of likely voters compared with Gore's 43 percent. Other polls also show that Bush holds a slight lead over Gore.

The real battle tomorrow will be for the 270 electoral votes needed to win the presidential election. A CNN analysis shows Bush with a lead in 26 states, worth 224 electoral votes combined. Gore has a lead in 12 states plus the District of Columbia, with a combined total of 181 electoral votes. In 12 other states, with a total of 133 electoral votes, neither candidate now has a clear edge.

These are some of today's top political stories. Be sure to stay with CNN for full election coverage. Tomorrow, our election coverage begins at 5:00 p.m. Eastern, 2:00 p.m. Pacific. Larry King will be joining the coverage throughout the night tomorrow. And I'll be bringing you late night coverage beginning at 1:00 a.m. Eastern Time.

Now we go back to New York and to Willow there.

BAY: Thanks, Joie.

Coming up on MONEYLINE, a major management shakeup at BMG sends president and CEO Strauss Zelnick walking. What pushed him out the door? We have the story.

Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: In tonight's CEO profile, John Chambers, king of networking giant Cisco. Chambers grew up in West Virginia, where he overcame dyslexia to graduate second in his high school class.

He began his career at IBM, joined Cisco in 1991, taking the CEO title just four years later.

He's led the company through unprecedented growth, presiding over nearly 70 acquisitions. An impressive feat, considering he says, quote, "My family is first, second and third in terms of my priorities."

Still, $10,000 invested when Chambers joined Cisco would be worth $2.8 million today. Just imagine if Cisco were priority No. 1.

MONEYLINE will be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: No relief in sight for euro. It dipped again today, despite another surprise effort to shore up the currency by the European central bank. For the second session in a row, the ECB intervened in the market to buys euros, and it did so without help from other countries. Today, the euro fell to just over 86 cents. Europe's common currency has fallen more than 25 percent against the dollar since its January 1999 debut. BAY: Some major fallout at German media giant Bertelsmann just days after the company announced its landmark deal with online music service Napster. Two of BMG's top execs are walking, and Casey Wian has the story.

Casey Wian has the story.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

CASEY WIAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): BMG Entertainment, the home of diverse music superstar such as Britney Spears, Whitney Houston and Santana is cleaning house. BMG's parent company, the German media giant Bertelsmann, announced the impending departure of BMG's top two executives: Chairman Michael Dornemann and president and CEO Strauss Zelnick.

Reportedly, both men were unwilling to accept diminished roles in the wake of a broader restructuring of Bertelsmann that will split the $17 billion privately held conglomerate into three business units and accelerate its transition away from traditional music retailing.

MARK MOORADIAN, JUPITER COMMUNICATIONS: Going forward, if you want to be in the growth business, you've got to be looking at things like downloads, things like subscription services and certainly at things like, given the growth of it, network file sharing.

WIAN: The catalyst for the resignations, which are effective at the end of the year, was BMG's controversial deal last week with Napster. It has agreed to help the online music-swapping service develop a business model in return for dropping out of the music industry's copyright infringement lawsuit against Napster.

ALEC FOEGE, MUSIC INDUSTRY WRITER: I think that you're going to find at a lot of the major labels people of a high rank stepping down in coming weeks and months because there is a huge amount of disagreement at the upper ranks.

WIAN: Disagreement over how to harness the profit potential of music distribution over the Internet while controlling piracy. The changes at the top of BMG help vindicate Arista Records founder Clive Davis. He was forced out of his job in May by the now-ousted Zelnick. Since then, Davis has received $150 million from Bertelsmann to start his own label, J Records, in partnership with BMG.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

WIAN: There have been reports in European newspapers that Bertelsmann ultimately plans to take Napster public. A company official we spoke with called that presumptuous and total speculation, Willow.

BAY: Casey, they could probably use a working business plan first.

WIAN: And a settlement of their lawsuit.

BAY: Casey Wian, thanks -- Stuart.

VARNEY: All right, Willow, in tonight's "Tech Watch," the pink slips at dot.com's keep piling up. Today, Furniture.com said it will layoff 76 of its 88 employees. The remaining workers will stick around just to shut down the site. Furniture.com, backed by CMGI, is the second online home furnishing business to close its doors this year. In august, Living.com shut down. That company was partly owned by Amazon.

And it's not just the dot.coms themselves suffering. Today, word came that a venture capital firm is slimming down itself. Divine Interventures says it will lay off 18 of its 41 employees. Shares of Divine finished today at 3 3/16, down more than 74 percent from their record high.

BAY: Coming up on MONEYLINE, the biggest media merger in history may soon get the nod from regulators. We'll get the details.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: There's a lot more ahead on the second half hour of MONEYLINE.

VARNEY: That's right. Cisco's after-the-bell earnings make the grade. We'll go one on one with the man in charge, chief executive and president John Chambers.

BAY: Plus, a triple-digit rally on the Dow, a closer look at this pre-election pop.

And if it's the economy, stupid, why isn't Al Gore looking at a landslide victory?

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ANNOUNCER: The MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR continues. Here again, Willow Bay in Los Angeles and Stuart Varney in New York.

BAY: In tonight's headlines, Cisco sails past profit and sales forecasts, but will another strong quarter be enough to win back frazzled investors? We'll talk with CEO John Chambers. And a one- time tech hot shot hits hard times: VA Linux warns of a revenue slide, laid low by a drop-off of dot.com business. Plus, with the election one day away, we look at a different kind of credit crunch. Why has Vice President Al Gore received so little credit for the longest economic boom in U.S. history?

VARNEY: But first, more on tonight's top story: A pre-election buying-spree sends the Dow soaring to a triple-digit again, as investors grabbed up some manufacturing mainstays and drug stocks ahead of the closest presidential election in decades.

Blue chips stocks pushed higher from the outset, gaining 159 points, closing at 10977. There volume there about 930 million. And leading the way was General Motors. It gained nearly four points. J.P. Morgan also up 4 3/4 there. 3M, United Technologies and Merck gained more than two points.

A different story on the Nasdaq, though, as investors shifted some funds out of tech stocks. That drove the Nasdaq down 35. It closed at 3416.

Now, check the movers there, JDS Uniphase down more than 3 3/4. Oracle and Sun Microsystems slipped nearly 2 1/2 piece. Nextel was down more than two. And Biogen lost more than 3 1/2.

BAY: The big tech news came after the bell when Cisco Systems edged past profit forecasts as the network equipment maker benefited from strong sales to Internet, cable and telecom companies. Cisco earned 18 cents a share, a 40 percent jump to $1.3 billion. This, driven by a 66 percent rise in revenue. The sales numbers also outpacing estimates.

In after-hours trading, Cisco stock shed 1 1/2. Later in the program, we'll hear from the man in charge, John Chambers, president and CEO of Cisco Systems.

VARNEY: A rough day for VA Linux systems. Shares of the company tanked more than 40 percent after it warned of a revenue shortfall in its fiscal first quarter, saying sales to new customers in the dot.com sector were below expectations. VA Linux dropped $12.50. It closed off more than 12 1/2 at 17 3/8. That beat its previous 52-week low of $23 a share. It is now down 95 percent from its 52-week high.

The sell-off weighed heavily on the entire sector. Amanda Lang joins us now from the Nasdaq marketsite in Times Square with all the details for us -- Amanda.

AMANDA LANG, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Thanks, Stuart. Well, shares of VA Linux did indeed tumble today after the company said it would disappoint investors when it reports its fiscal first quarter in two weeks time.

The company had been expected to lose 9 cents a share, but it said it could lose almost double that amount. VA Linux did indeed say that it had softer-than-expected revenue in the quarter, and it blamed slower spending by some of its dot.com customers for the shortfall.

It was that explanation that helped rattle other Linux-related companies. Those Internet startups had been among the most loyal adherents for Linux, the open-source operating system seen as a potential rival for Microsoft.

Rival Linux firm Redhat, which itself disappointed the Street recently with weaker-than-expected revenue, fell on the warning from its rival, ending down more than 7 percent. And Caldera Systems ended the day down almost 10 percent.

Analysts were mixed today as to whether the whole sector should be tarred with the same brush, with many stressing that the adoption rates of Linux will likely remain strong. But while many Linux firms are working to broaden their customer base beyond the traditional dot.com clientele, larger corporate customers take much longer to make buying decision. So that while VA Linux did increase its customer base to include some more traditional firms, revenue from those customers won't show up this fiscal quarter.

Back to you, Stuart.

VARNEY: And that is Amanda Lang. Thanks very much, Amanda -- Willow.

BAY: Stuart, as we said, stocks on that New York Stock Exchange rallied today as many investors bet on a Bush victory, the time winding down on a long, tough political campaign.

A perplexing phenomenon has put the Democrats at an apparent disadvantage. While the Clinton administration has presided over eight years of unprecedented prosperity, Al Gore does not seem to be getting much credit.

Terry Keenan at the New York Stock Exchange takes a look at why not -- Terry.

TERRY KEENAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Well, Willow, after Bill Clinton captured the White House in 1992 by focusing laser-like on the economy, any first-year poli-sci major could tell you that the key to winning a presidential economy -- election, that is, was the economy. Well, that's why this year is so confounding to the so-called "experts."

By any measure, Al Gore has the economic wind at his back with unemployment at the lowest level in a generation, an almost decade- long expansion, and tame inflation. In fact, given these factors, one noted professor at the University of Iowa, with a long track record of calling elections, believes the vice president should be 10 points ahead in the polls.

Well, with most polls showing Governor Bush with the advantage, many pollsters are trying to figure out what's going on this year, and there are several schools of thought. But many experts say the vice president hasn't done a good job of linking himself to the prosperity, and that is particularly important this year, because so many voters are blase about the economic boom.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GEOFFREY GARIN, PETER D. HART & ASSOCIATES: Frankly, people think that this economy is so good now that nobody is going to mess it up, and there's really not a consciousness that the economy is in jeopardy one way or the other in this election. And that's obviously been a disadvantage to Gore.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KEENAN: Well, then there are the conflicting signals from the stock market. Typically, a presidential election year is a very good year for stocks, with the S&P 500 up an average of 11 percent. But this year, the S&P is down more than 2 percent and the Nasdaq is off 16 percent in an election where more voters own stock than ever before.

So not apparently a typical year by any measure when you look at how voters are likely to vote their pocketbooks -- Willow.

BAY: So, Terry, is it clear -- is it clear that the market is expecting a Bush victory?

KEENAN: You know, there's all sorts of indicators. There's the one that I just showed you. This will be the first year that the S&P 500 is down in a presidential election year since 1960. On the other hand, some people like to look at the short-term trend of the Dow over the last two or three months. If you look at that, that would be a positive for Gore, because the Dow is up over the last couple of months, but the Nasdaq is down and down a lot.

BAY: All right, and we'll find out tomorrow.

KEENAN: That's for sure.

BAY: Terry Keenan, thanks -- Stuart.

VARNEY: Willow, next on MONEYLINE, more on why Al Gore is not getting a bigger boost from a super-strong economy. We'll talk with two veteran Wall Street economists, Robert Brusca and David Jones. We'll be back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: More now on what seems to be an election paradox: why the vice president hasn't gotten much political capital from an economy that is going very strongly. At the Democratic convention, President Clinton invoked Ronald Reagan by asking: "Are you better off now than you were eight years ago?"

All right, let's look at some statistics. Back in 1992, unemployment was higher than 7 percent. Now, it's at 3.9 percent, and that's a 30-year low. The yield on the long bond has fallen more than a point and a half. The Dow has more than tripled from where it closed the night before the '92 election. And the Nasdaq has soared, I should say, more than 450 percent.

So why hasn't Mr. Gore gotten more credit for the boom, and how much of the credit does the Clinton administration truly deserve?

Joining us now economists Robert Brusca and David Jones. Gentlemen, welcome to MONEYLINE.

If Mr. Gore and Mr. Clinton are not going to get the credit, who does deserve the credit? Go first, David.

DAVID JONES, AUBREY G. LANSTON: Private sector, Stuart. The driving force behind this 10-year expansion is a high-tech investment boom and a high-tech revolution in effect, which has pushed up productivity growth, given the chance for the economy to grow faster, efficient capital markets moving the capital to the high-return sectors where the technology revolution went, and finally, a Clinton administration, which I will admit, had two architects of this expansion, Alan Greenspan and former Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin. It's very difficult to transfer from them to Gore this great economic miracle.

VARNEY: All right, Bob, who get's the credit?

ROBERT BRUSCA, ECOBEST CONSULTING: Well, I'd like to look back at antecedents. I think we go to George's father. I think that Bush had the economy improving during the elections. People didn't realize it. This is a guy who won Desert Storm, who had an economy that was improving with a Fed chairman who was being stingy with interest rates. And, you know, I want to know why he didn't get more credit. You want to know why Gore doesn't get credit. Why didn't Bush Senior get more credit for what he did?

I think the American people are kind of picky in the way they look at things. Also, you want to give credit to monetary policy, give it to Paul Volker and Alan Greenspan. Volker knocked inflation down. Greenspan has kept it out for the count.

VARNEY: What about the Republican Congress that came in 1994? Because the Dow really rocketed and the economy took off after the Republicans won in November of '94.

BRUSCA: Well, that's true, and, of course, you go back farther to Ronald Reagan, who really put the economy on a different path. I mean, this is a long, long process. You know, fiscal policy takes a long time to work out. This is why it's not really suited for cyclical kinds of problems and why you take a look at this economy, we're headed for this big tax cut if we get Mr. Bush in office. We're at full employment. You have to wonder what that's going to do to this economy.

There are questions about fiscal policy right now, I think. And both of them are going to get rid of the surplus. They are going to do it different in different ways, and this surplus may not even be real. We've got two presidents, two presidential candidates, out to destroy something that may not be real.

VARNEY: Does Mr. Gore deserve any of the blame for what's happened to Microsoft?

JONES: Well, let's put it this way. If I were voting for Gore, and I'll make that a hypothetical, I would expect him to be very tough on business because he's running a campaign that has sounded very tough on business, whether it's price controls on the pharmaceuticals, whether it's continuing the antitrust action against Microsoft. So, I would argue that Gore is an automatic negative for the stock market, for example.

And one of the reasons the stock market has been pushing higher has been a Bush phenomenon. As he has looked better in the polls, the market's done better.

VARNEY: Do you think that Mr. Gore should get some of the credit for NAFTA, which did introduce competition to many American corporations?

BRUSCA: You know, I have a problem with giving him credit, giving him blame, because this man is the vice president. Since when has the vice president run an administration that he is the vice president in? I mean, he was the vice president. He wasn't making the decisions. And furthermore, when he ran his campaign for election, he tried to distance himself from Mr. Clinton because of all that other political baggage Mr. Clinton had. Now, how can he have it both ways? How can he distance himself from him and then embrace the successes at the same time?

VARNEY: Should he have embraced Mr. Clinton's performance?

BRUSCA: Well, if you take a look at what happened in the debates, in the debates, Mr. Gore made some mistakes. He started looking a lot like Mr. Clinton. People have basically put him together with velcro and now he's attached to Mr. Clinton but he doesn't get those successes either. I think he's got the worst of all worlds. I think it's a tactical mistake in the way this is run and I really don't think in any true terms he deserves any credit for it because he wasn't the architect. He was me too.

VARNEY: Just let me tell you, let me know how you really feel about this, Bob, OK? Predictions: has Mr. Bush got this sewn up?

JONES: I think it's going to be a splitster. You mentioned it earlier: Bush president, one of the two houses of Congress will go Democratic. The public loves those kinds of things because not too much damage is done, even with fiscal policy.

BRUSCA: Well, it's no landslide for anybody. I think it looks like Bush is ahead. I would agree with David in this scenario. And I think that means that we muddle through another four years where we don't get any dramatic changes in policy. But if Bush does get elected, he's going to have to try like crazy to have some kind of a tax cut go through but it won't look anything like the one he's proposing.

VARNEY: Fair enough.

Bob Brusca, David Jones, many thanks for being here tonight.

JONES: Thank you.

BRUSCA: Thank you,

VARNEY: Willow.

BAY: Stuart, coming up next, Nasdaq heavyweight Cisco beats the street by a penny again. We'll have the man in charge, John Chambers, Cisco's president and CEO, when we return.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: Topping tonight's "MONEYLINE Movers," telecom equipment maker Turnstone Systems plunged more than $19. The company lowered its revenue estimates to $38 million, far short of the $56 million Wall Street expected.

Palm lost more than 4 1/2 on news that its competitor, Symbian, has a head-start on new smart phone technology.

But Equinox Systems jumped more than 2 1/4 on nearly 88 times its average volume. Avocent will pay $57 million in cash for the communications software company.

And British Airways gained nearly 4 1/2. The airline announced today that operating profit more than doubled and that it will sell its low-fare subsidiary.

VARNEY: In other corporate news, a transatlantic energy deal between New York's Amerada Hess and Britain's Lasmo. The merger gives Hess a bigger international position and an expanded role in oil exploration and production. And chalk up another deal for Broadcom. The high-speed communications company announced its 11th purchase this year: a $2 billion deal for chip maker Sibyte. Broadcom said the deal would trim profits next year, but add to earnings in 2002. Broadcom, today, it's stock fell nearly 3 1/2, down to $219 a share.

BAY: Tonight, Cisco does it again. As we told you earlier, after the bell earning's from the routing giant did not disappoint, beating the street by a penny a share. However, in after-hours trading. shares are down 1 1/2. Cisco, traditionally a Nasdaq standout, is up just about 3 percent this year and is off its highs by more than 30 percent.

Joining us now to talk about tonight's earnings news and what's in store for next year, Cisco president and CEO, John Chambers.

John, as always, welcome to MONEYLINE.

JOHN CHAMBERS, CEO, CISCO SYSTEMS: Thank you, Willow. Pleasure to be here.

BAY: I'd like to start, if I may, with your guidance. You guided street upwards for your second quarter and for 2001. What's behind the bullishness?

CHAMBERS: Well, we don't have a much more aggressive call than we had this quarter and last quarter. Our growth rate of 66 percent is double what the market anticipated, just like in March of this last year. We saw geographic balance across all five of our key geographies, across all of our lines of business and across nine out of or 12 product lines through $1 billion plus in a way we've not seen it before, as well.

Each of the five geographies had over 50 percent year-over-year growth, and all of them grew double digits, Q4 to Q1. Our lines of business were really solid with the reemergence of enterprise and small to medium business growing in over 20 percent. And the balance across the product lines were unusually good. So, we're very optimistic. We're in the early innings of this new ball game, if you will. BAY: John, just explain, if you would, why balance is so important to you. It's a theme that comes up again and again after your earnings.

CHAMBERS: Well, customers are moving to an end-to-end provider, so you have got to have multiple products to be able to provide that either in enterprise or service provider. Secondly, if you are too dependent on one market segment and that market segment goes through bumps, as all of them will, you look good when it's going well, but you look very bad when it's going the other way.

And the third element is enterprise customers and service provider customers, they share networks. And the extent to which enterprise customers outsource will determine how fast service providers grow. But Cisco's positioned either way it goes. If they outsource more of their networks, then we're well positioned in service providers. If they continue to build them up at the current pace, which is actually accelerating internally, we're in a good position there as well. So, it's that balance that I think is so unique to Cisco.

BAY: Let's talk about what you're seeing going forward in the telecom sector. Are you seeing signs of a slowdown? And what about from the upstarts that make up about 15 percent of your revenues?

CHAMBERS: We're seeing very good balance on all the theaters outside the U.S. So, we saw the double-digit growth as we had expected and service providers outside U.S. Inside U.S., the selects were sluggish. Our balance on products was very good. Opticals on fair, it grew 40 percent over last quarter, 500 percent over a year ago. Momentum looks very good, good balance across the product lines. So with the exception CLEX and one or two major service providers, we're in pretty good shape on a global basis.

Capital…

BAY: What about…

CHAMBERS: Go ahead.

BAY: I was going to say, what about those loan commitments that you have, two -- a little over $2 billion. Do you have any credit concerns going forward?

CHAMBERS: Well I always have concerns about anything. I think any company that isn't paranoid doesn't survive in this industry.

Having said that, we're very conservative in our financial recognition, and Larry is accruing within very acceptable guidelines. We're much more conservative than our peers, so I would be surprised and disappointed if this were an issue at all.

BAY: John Chambers, as always, thanks for joining us.

CHAMBERS: Willow, our pleasure. Thank you.

BAY: Stuart.

VARNEY: Coming up next, AOL-Time Warner: from high-fives to a high-stakes regulatory battle. We'll have the latest on where this media merger stands when we return.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: A resolution today to antitrust charges against the fourth and fifth biggest U.S. airlines. Northwest agreed to give up its voting control of Continental Airlines, a stake that Northwest acquired two years ago. Under the proposed plan agreed to by the Justice Department, Northwest will sell most of its voting shares back to Continental for $450 million. But Northwest would hold on to shares with reduced voting power and retain the ability to block the future sale of Continental to another airline.

Checking the stocks, Northwest was unchanged, but Continental fell three.

VARNEY: We now take a look at another regulatory hot button that has made headlines over the past 10 months: the proposed merger of America Online and Time Warner, the parent of CNN. Now corporate America's biggest deal ever may be nearing approval.

Greg Clarkin has been following the ups and downs of the regulatory process, and he joins us now for an update.

What do you have, Greg?

GREG CLARKIN, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Well, Stuart, ever since this deal was announced in January, the hot-button issue has been open access to Time Warner's cable lines. Now this is an issue that regulators have focused on and one that appears, at least, to be close to being resolved.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

(voice-over): The Federal Trade Commission and America Online and Time Warner are moving closer to an agreement over open access. Sources say a final deal on open access could be struck as early as the end of this week, which would clear one of the biggest hurdles for AOL and Time Warner's proposed merger. Time Warner is parent of CNN.

Since the deal was announced in January, executives of both companies have promised open access. But they've bristled at the suggestion regulators should dictate the terms. So word the companies may be close to agreeing to open access terms was encouraging to consumer activists.

GENE KIMMELMAN, CONSUMERS UNION: This is an important step forward, because we finally have AOL and Time Warner admitting that a promise isn't enough. They dominate the Internet service marketplace, they control 20 percent of all cable distribution, have a partnership with AT&T for another 30 percent. That's half the country. They have an ownership stake together between the two companies and about half of the most popular programs. They finally admit that they can't just make promises.

CLARKIN: Among the possible conditions being discussed is a requirement that at least one Internet service provider, or ISP, gain access to Time Warner cable lines before AOL service is offered.

Another possibility: depending on conditions of a specific market, AOL/Time Warner could be required to carry at least three other ISPs.

Just what will be sent over those high-speed cable lines has been the driving force behind this deal from day one.

FRED MORAN, JEFFRIES & CO.: The benefit to Time Warner is they have AOL's marketing muscle behind cable modems. They can not only go out there and market through their cable systems, but they can go out and market directly over the Web to all of AOL's customers and push those customers on to higher speed access, which not only increases your monthly bill from a subscription standpoint, but also will allow you to take streaming video and broadband services, which will stimulate even more time on the Web.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CLARKIN: And while the options being discussed do provide some degree of open access to Time Warner's cable lines, they don't satisfy some consumer activists, who want to see the lines open to any and all ISPs -- Stuart.

VARNEY: Greg Clarkin, thanks very much.

Let's bring you up to date on the stocks: AOL up 2 1/2 points today, and Time Warner gained 4 -- Willow.

BAY: Stuart, up next, "Ahead of the Curve," some of what you need to know tonight before tomorrow's markets open.

You're watching MONEYLINE.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: Taking a look at some of what could move the markets tomorrow, watch for quarterly earnings from BP-Amoco and Abercrombie & Fitch.

And in case you're unclear as to which Tuesday tomorrow is, it's, of course, Election Day. Tune in to CNN for extensive Election Day coverage.

To stay a step ahead of the markets, tune in to "Ahead of the Curve" at 5:00 a.m. Eastern, right here on CNN.

And MONEYLINE would like to hear from you, so send us your comments by e-mail to moneyline@cnn.com.

That is MONEYLINE for this Monday. I'm Willow Bay.

VARNEY: And I'm Stuart Varney.

Good night from New York. CROSSFIRE is next,

FT subscribers can click here to receive tech news daily by email in the #techFT newsletter

One benefit of darker evenings as autumn approaches is earlier appreciation of how the Thames is being lit near the FT's offices. From London Bridge to the Millennium Bridge, four spans have been subtly wired with an ever-changing lighting system, the work of the artist Leo Villareal, who carried out a similar project on the Bay Bridge in San Francisco.

Fifteen Thames bridges will eventually be lit by the Illuminated River Foundation, with Philips lighting spin-off   Signify providing the technology. Signify is changing this city and many others after dark, and even in daytime, in the multifarious ways that lighting is becoming a platform through   the LEDification of the world.

The advantages of LEDs over conventional lighting, in terms of their long life and energy and cost savings, have been understood for years, but the ability to control them and add sensors and other chips to the mix, connected through the Internet of Things, has vastly enhanced the possibilities of technology that already has a huge installed base of light sockets and lampposts.

Joao Pola, chief executive of Signify in the UK, gave me examples such as the local council here which controls street lights so they show a pathway for crowds exiting a stadium, while another hands over control of street lighting levels to restaurants and shops to help create an ambience. In Los Angeles, there are audio sensors in lighting that can detect disturbances in the middle of the night and are used by police to literally shine a light on what's happening. Street lamps elsewhere enable levels of pollution, salt on the roads and any flooding to be monitored.

Signify is also mimicking natural light in windowless offices to improve working conditions and providing 150Mb/s local connectivity inside workplaces with LiFi technology. Vertical farms, where lighting can make growing crops more efficient, and light shows in stadiums are other expanding areas, and Signify is best known to consumers as Philips Hue, the lighting system for smart homes (see Tech Tools below for its latest product).

“It's technology that can enhance people's lives at home, as citizens seeing monuments and bridges lit up, it can make them more productive and feel better in the office, we're taking things to the next level of experience,” says Mr Pola.

The Internet of (Five) Things

1. Netflix watching you watching Netflix
The smart TVs in our homes are leaking sensitive user data to companies including Netflix, Google and Facebook even when some devices are idle, according to this scoop from Madhumita Murgia. Researchers from Northeastern University and Imperial College London found that a number of smart TVs, including those made by Samsung and LG, and the streaming dongles Roku and Amazon’s FireTV, were sending out data such as location and IP address to Netflix and third-party advertisers.

2. Huawei says it will share 5G tech
Chinese technology group Huawei is spending $1.5bn to recruit software developers for its computing platforms and offering to share its 5G technology through licensing, as it seeks new partners in the face of US sanctions that cut it off from suppliers including Google. Huawei’s search for more developers is made urgent by the fact that its new Mate smartphones, to be launched in Munich on Thursday, will not have licensed access to Google’s apps.

3. WeWork founder 'humbled'
WeWork’s chief executive Adam Neumann has told employees he had been “humbled” by the aborted initial public offering of his lossmaking property group, admitting he needed to learn lessons about running a public company. John Gapper comments that it is a touchy moment for founders who convince venture capitalists that technology and a new business model can change the world.

4. US antitrust overlap
Are there too many overlapping US antitrust investigations of Big Tech, with the Federal Trade Commission, Justice department and state attorneys-general all getting involved. The FTC's chairman Joseph Simons and  Makan Delrahim, head of the justice department’s antitrust division, both conceded at a Senate judiciary committee hearing that the overlap in their investigations into the tech industry was inefficient and caused confusion.

5. Drones for war and peace
Lex says regulators are limiting the scope of drones and best use cases may be for good causes such as the delivery of life-saving remedies or organs in Africa. We've also an analysis on the increasing use of armed drones in the Middle East and how best to defend against them.

Forwarded from our Tech Scroll Asia newsletter

A SoftBank-cool wind is casting a pall over Asia's tech start-up universe, the latest sign of the widening fallout of the ill-fated WeWork IPO. Read more about the sterner emphasis on profitability that is zipping through the region as a result in this week's Tech Scroll Asia.

Tech tools — Philips Hue Play HDMI Sync Box

The Philips Hue Play HDMI Sync Box, launched this week, allows users to sync Philips Hue lights with their TV, enabling more immersive experiences with music, movies and video games. The box is plugged in between any HDMI device and the TV and alters the speed, intensity and colours of Hue lights installed around the TV to match the mood of what's being watched.

George Yianni, head of Technology for Philips Hue and its founder, explained to me that the tech is different from Philips Ambilight TVs which makes screens seem bigger by taking colours inside them and shining them out on to the surroundings. “What we're doing is looking at the whole screen and extracting 3D information and bringing this into the third dimension,” he said. The box is available from October 15 at €249.95 in continental Europe (UK release comes later) and $229.99 in the US.
